body:
[Conditional compilation](http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html#conditional-compilation) is a feature that was inherited from Pyrex that never had a high standing amongst the Cython developers. It also takes up quite a bit of code space in the syntax nodes and the parser and allows incorrect user assumptions about the data values used in the code (e.g. the precision of floating point numbers).

See the discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4287

I would like to deprecate it in Cython 3.0 and add a warning.
~It could be one of the things that we remove for Cython 3.1.~ It will not be removed in Cython 3.1, but continue to be available for another couple of release series, so that users have enough time to move away from it.

Usages of `DEF` should be replaced by:
- global cdef constants
- global enums (C or Python)
- C macros, e.g. defined in [verbatim C code sections](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code)

Usages of `IF` should be replaced by:
- leaving out unused C struct field names from a Cython struct definition (which does not have to be complete)
- redefining a struct type under different Cython names, with different (e.g. version/platform dependent) attributes, but - runtime conditions with the [same cname string](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#resolving-naming-conflicts-c-name-specifications).
- separating out optional (non-trivial) functionality into optional Cython modules and importing/using them at need
- code generation, as a last resort

It is generally preferable to take a C compiler related decision at C compile time rather than Cython translation time. This avoids having to generate multiple versions of the C file. Especially platform dependent adaptations are really best handled in C macros, e.g.
```cython
cdef extern from "some_external_lib.h":
    """"
    #define HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD (C_LIB_VERSION >= 20)

    #if HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD
        #define _mylib_get_newly_added_field(a_struct_ptr)  ((a_struct_ptr)->newly_added_field)
    #else
        #define _mylib_get_newly_added_field(a_struct_ptr)  (0)
    #endif
    """"
    bint HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD
    int get_newly_added_field "_mylib_get_newly_added_field" (struct_ptr)

if HAS_NEWLY_ADDED_FIELD:
    print(get_newly_added_field(some_struct_ptr))
```

comment_data.body:
I'd be in favour in principle.

It might be worth trying to work out how much real code it'll break. I'm not completely sure the best way to do that right now - possibly by scraping [the PyPI dependent packages](https://libraries.io/pypi/Cython/dependents)?

A quick check of scipy turned up [this use](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/44e31b1eb202ef91caad059952ba268d2610a60b/scipy/stats/biasedurn.pyx.templ#L10) so at least one project would need some adapting.

```
DEF NPY_OLD = {NPY_OLD}
...
IF not NPY_OLD:
```

Although this is a niche feature, it can be used.
But I agree that the likelihood is high that there will be more pythonic ways to achieve the same result.
Both DEF and IF are quite useful for imports, since it doesn't make much sense to check for something at interpretation time that can be checked at compile time.

In short, DEF and IF benefit from whatever is determined at compile time.

While not many people think about it, what about UB/IB handling?
For example `INT_MIN / -1` for c++
in the case when `INT_MIN! = -INT_MAX` we must define the behavior of `INT_MIN / -1` ourselves, so as not to accidentally get stuck in an infinite loop, or so that our calculations do not suddenly return an incorrect result.
It is very convenient to wrap it in IF:

```cython
int safe_int_div(int a, int b):
    if b == 0:
        return 1

    IF INT_MIN != -INT_MAX:
        if a == INT_MIN and b == -1:
            return 1

    return a / b
```

Also numpy project is using them:

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/623bc1fae1d47df24e7f1e29321d0c0ba2771ce0/numpy/random/_philox.pyx#L14
pyimgui uses [DEF](https://github.com/pyimgui/pyimgui/blob/480b4de8ab82adaa2cd310100330b41f40274bcc/imgui/core.pyx#L37)
Some scipy tutorial uses [DEF](https://github.com/kwmsmith/scipy-2017-cython-tutorial/blob/3e72e31fc27dc1f44582926f4a01a4c29ee79abb/cython_mcmc/cython_mcmc/mcmc.pyx#L10-L11)

As I understand the discussion, `DEF` is OK, it is the `IF` that is more troubling (the "conditional" in "conditional compliation". Also: too many examples is going to make this discussion unwieldy. Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it. I apologize for starting it off.

> too many examples is going to make this discussion unwieldy. Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it.

of course, just a couple of examples, no more needed here
PyBoy uses [IF](https://github.com/Baekalfen/PyBoy/blob/b39a988e263d9830701d35d426fcd143d25e9ac9/pyboy/core/lcd.pxd#L30)

> ```cython
>     IF INT_MIN != -INT_MAX:
> ```

This is decidedly _NOT_ a use case for conditional compilation. It should be handled at C compile time.

> It should be handled at C compile time.

exactly, and as I understand it, cython cannot convert this expression to `#ifdef` and pass it to the compiler?

To clarify, what takes up code space is the separate calculation of constant values in the parser (i.e. `DEF`). The conditional statements (' IF'  etc.) are trivial compared to that. They are just a wart in the language.

I would personally like to see `IF` removed, at some point. I could live with keeping a way to define constants, although I don't think they'd have to be handled by the compiler. We already do constant folding (although we do not inject all constant values in the end, e.g. floats to prevent loss/gain of precision). I could imagine something like a `cython.once()` which would make sure that an expression is only evaluated once (and then cached, or, if compile time constant, injected as a constant at compile time). OTOH, I'm not sure it's worth breaking existing code for that.

The [use case in SciPy](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/44e31b1eb202ef91caad059952ba268d2610a60b/scipy/stats/biasedurn.pyx.templ#L77) is an exemplary one, if I understand it correctly. It seems to be using template code generation to inject a constant flag, but then uses `IF` to switch between different code sections. Why not use the templating language for that?

I'm sure users are still writing such code as we're discussing this, and IMHO they shouldn't. I've added a warning to the documentation and would also like to add a visible compile time deprecation warning. Would that be ok for everyone?

Then we can discuss the removal again in a couple of years from now, maybe with a better standing.

> Perhaps we should create a document with all the questionable usages and link to it

here are some examples #4314
@scoder to fully understand when the behavior of `IF` will differ from `if`?  Or like what's the difference?

> @scoder to fully understand when the behavior of `IF` will differ from `if`? Or like what's the difference?

To be more specific, what legit `IF` expression will not have the same result as if we replace `IF` with `if`?

> add a visible compile time deprecation warning

That sounds like a good plan, and would encourage people to not use it.

I would be in favor of deprecating as well. 

Some `IF` expressions that would not be legal if replaced by if are those that use, for example, nonexistent or differently typed function calls in the different branches. (Either templating or a C-level shim can be used instead.)

It seems that most uses of `DEF` could be replaced by a global variable as well, though it's possible that would hurt the ability to optimize away some things at the C level even for a sophisticated compiler (for full expressions, literal constants should be fine). In a few cases (array sizes) we require a constant. Perhaps we could be smart enough here with an "ordinary" global.

Please be mindful of use cases like https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4291, which CuPy relies on a lot. Sorry I don't have time to open a discussion in the mailing list yet, but it doesn't mean I don't care...

cc: @kmaehashi

Yeah this is pretty useful when detecting the version of a dependency before adding certain code (like forward declarations or handling other differences between library versions). Have used `IF` to handle differences between Python versions specifically.

> As I understand the discussion, `DEF` is OK, it is the `IF` that is more troubling (the "conditional" in "conditional compliation"

Well, @mattip idk, but it looks like [`DEF` is not OK](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4286#issuecomment-887222354), at least @scoder doesn't really want to leave this in cython as I understand it

I added a deprecation warning for both `DEF` and `IF`, as well as some explanations and examples in the docs.

Please keep commenting in this ticket if you have a use case that is not easily replaced with something else.

What features should users be reaching for if they want to include/exclude a block of code based on a compile time setting?

For example optionally building with a library (say `liba.so`) where forward declarations and API calls to it should be included/excluded based on whether library is used during the build.

In general, C compile time features rather than Cython translation time features. Generating different C files is rarely a good idea.

A common thing to do is to write configuration dependent shims and then call those instead of the actual library API.

Removing `DEF` is OK, but without `IF` as part of the Cython compile-time preprocesser it's really hard to maintain the codebase without rolling out a code generator of our own.

cc: @kmaehashi @vzhurba01

I looked through CuPy a bit. There are large chunks of multiply defined structs like here:
https://github.com/cupy/cupy/blob/76f3f85f14842685b4b8048f22536f39d2079c92/cupy_backends/cuda/api/_runtime_typedef.pxi
I certainly don't understand enough of it to give "final" answers (and this is the wrong place to discuss this in detail), but here are a couple of ideas how I could try to handle this. I [added examples](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code) to the docs.

For simple cases, I'd resort to writing C macro shims that give different implementations a common interface.

For more complex cases, especially with different but similar backend libraries, I'd consider implementing separate low-level extension modules and importing one or the other. I do not mean duplicating all of CuPy, not at all. But I'd investigate, for example, if I could provide a (shallow) common wrapper type with C methods that I could subclass into different implementations that work with different libraries in the end. That way, the different low-level structs and API differences would stay inside of those low-level modules, and the main user level API modules would only talk to the internal API of the low-level modules.

So, basically, the idea is to hide differences behind another level of indirection.

That said, this is what I would do when designing a new system. Applying this to an existing code base, especially an existing large code base, is  probably not done lightly. I'm aware that this is an issue.
I think https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2596 should be the most general way forward for this.

I'm changing the milestone to 3.0 because this ticket is about the deprecation. Removing the feature in 3.1 would be way too soon, but there will be a deprecation warning in 3.0 (and preferably already in 0.29.x) to keep new users from starting to use it in their code. The feature will probably stay available for another couple of years (and it wouldn't be the first such feature). That should give all of you enough time to move away from it and find better ways to do what you need.

Either [C macros](https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code) or Cython code generation (#2596) should generally cover all use cases.

How should constants be declared right now? It doesn't actually seem like it's possible - as this [test shows](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/325641c5067163d5d20f3846e091a8cf18f1bfeb/tests/errors/const_decl_errors.pyx#L8), trying the following results in a "can't assign to const" error:
```cython
cdef const int x = 10
```
It does seem possible to workaround by using a verbatim C block, but that hides the constant's value from Cython preventing it from converting `if char in CONST_STRING` to a `switch`, which I'm using.

> How should constants be declared right now?

What's the specific need for constants? Is it missed optimisations (like your switch example) or are there more fundamental things that you need them for?

Python has largely taken the view that constants are a matter of convention rather than something that's enforced, so it isn't too unreasonable for Cython to take that view too (although not at the cost of blocking anything important from working...)

It's mostly optimisation yes, though as mentioned earlier there's things like array sizes that require constant values. Regular Python is mutable everywhere yes, but Cython is much more static in a lot of ways - monkeypatching builtins, extension classes, functions is ignored for the most part. Using `cdef` also would suggest you're after more C-like semantics.

The thing is, just to define a constant, we don't need the whole Python value computation machinery that `DEF` adds to the parser. It would be enough to define constants in `setup.py` and add them to some internal namespace. Or finally implement `cdef const ... =`. Or, inject them with code generation, which covers a whole lot more use cases.

`warning: View.MemoryView:323:0: The 'DEF' statement is deprecated and will be removed ...`
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Utility/MemoryView.pyx#L323

``` cython
DEF THREAD_LOCKS_PREALLOCATED = 8

# with:
cdef enum:
    THREAD_LOCKS_PREALLOCATED = 8
```
(Sorry I dropped the ball, bumping myself @leofang to check back asap.)

> `warning: View.MemoryView:323:0: The 'DEF' statement is deprecated and will be removed ...`

Fixed via code generation (which that module used anyway).
Why `DEF` cannot be used in version 0.29.30

> Why `DEF` cannot be used in version 0.29.30

It can, but it's deprecated. So you get a warning if you use it (not an error).

> > Why `DEF` cannot be used in version 0.29.30
> 
> It can, but it's deprecated. So you get a warning if you use it (not an error).

If I only used `DEF`, I will get nothing.If I used `DEF` to define  a constant in `pxd`, and used the constant in `pyx`, I will get
```
Error compiling Cython file:
------------------------------------------------------------
...
# cython: language_level=3
from libc.stdio cimport printf


cpdef test():
    printf("%d", ArraySize)                ^
------------------------------------------------------------

test_DEF.pyx:6:17: undeclared name not builtin: ArraySize

```
test_DEF.pyx:
```

from libc.stdio cimport printf


cpdef test():
    printf("%d", ArraySize)
```
test_DEF.pxd:
```
# cython: language_level=3
DEF FavouriteFood = u"spam"
DEF ArraySize = 41
DEF OtherArraySize = 1 * ArraySize + 17

cdef int a0[ArraySize]
cdef int a1[OtherArraySize]
```
Is this something that worked before Cython 0.29.30 or new code?

>  Cython 0.29.30 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44611975/176234099-934a4b85-0409-4e98-9407-62a71ebc343d.png)

It tried a few versions back to 0.28.1 and it didn't work on any of them. Therefore I think we just conclude that `DEF` variables do not cross the .pxd->.pyx boundary. Given that it's not a regression and a deprecated feature I think this is "won't fix"
Is there an option somewhere to treat compilation warnings as errors so we can make sure no deprecated API is used via CI ?

> Is there an option somewhere to treat compilation warnings as errors so we can make sure no deprecated API is used via CI ?

The cython command has a `-Werror` argument

> I added a deprecation warning for both `DEF` and `IF`, as well as some explanations and examples in the docs.
> 
> Please keep commenting in this ticket if you have a use case that is not easily replaced with something else.

Can you update the docs to show the correct way to do platform specific conditional statements.
https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html#conditional-statements

I saw that you added a partial example linked above but I don't know how to apply it to mac and linux.
https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code

My use case is importing functions from a dynamic library. I have platform conditional statements to define a function that loads the dll functions.
https://github.com/Amulet-Team/Amulet-Core/blob/fix-leveldb2/amulet/libs/leveldb/leveldb.pyx#L26-L57

@gentlegiantJGC in this example you can see that you write a code to include platform specific stuff
https://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code
```cython
cdef extern from *:
    """
    #if defined(_WIN32) || defined(MS_WINDOWS) || defined(_MSC_VER)
      #include "stdlib.h"
      #define myapp_sleep(m)  _sleep(m)
    #else
      #include <unistd.h>
      #define myapp_sleep(m)  ((void) usleep((m) * 1000))
    #endif
    """
    # using "myapp_" prefix in the C code to prevent C naming conflicts
    void msleep "myapp_sleep"(int milliseconds) nogil

msleep(milliseconds=1)
```

Although I would recommend to just create a `.c` or `.h` file (of both) and then use `cdef extern from` on it:
```c
// independent.h
#if defined(_WIN32) || defined(MS_WINDOWS) || defined(_MSC_VER)
  #include "stdlib.h"
  #define myapp_sleep(m)  _sleep(m)
#else
  #include <unistd.h>
  #define myapp_sleep(m)  ((void) usleep((m) * 1000))
#endif
```
```cython
cdef extern from "independent.h":
    void myapp_sleep(int milliseconds) nogil

myapp_sleep(milliseconds=1)
```

In your case you can do the same thing with the platform specific code
And then just `cdef extern` so you will have access to the `getFunction`

It does seem like a bit of a step backwards because it requires writing pure C code to achieve something that could previously be done directly in Cython.
As a user that doesn't really know C it does make it a lot harder.
Here is my implementation.
<https://github.com/Amulet-Team/Amulet-LevelDB/blob/main/leveldb/_leveldb.pyx#L21-L73>

You don't have to move everything to c, only neessesary platform dependent parts
But yeah, I can see that documenation mey be little more helpful regarding this

pyproj passes arguments in compile time (https://github.com/pyproj4/pyproj/blob/f20266218f54444991e779b449f5fe507a008f16/setup.py#L199-L204) for conditional statements.

Here are the use cases (https://github.com/pyproj4/pyproj/search?q=CTE):
- passing in the python implementation: https://github.com/pyproj4/pyproj/blob/f20266218f54444991e779b449f5fe507a008f16/pyproj/_compat.pyx#L20-L31
- checking the PROJ version to see if a method is available for use: https://github.com/pyproj4/pyproj/blob/f20266218f54444991e779b449f5fe507a008f16/pyproj/_transformer.pyx#L33-L35

rasterio also passes in arguments in compile time (https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/blob/24db5b36700e71fdb37866d185c2d5547c531783/setup.py#L257) for conditional statements to check the GDAL version.
See: https://github.com/rasterio/rasterio/search?q=CTE_GDAL_MAJOR_VERSION

What is the recommended path forward since conditional statements are now deprecated?

I am going to be very sad to see this feature go. It has been very beneficial to be able to use these conditionals to write cython code within compile time arguments instead of having to move to C-level workarounds.

Issue in pyproj for why the python implementation was needed at compile time: https://github.com/pyproj4/pyproj/issues/854. Suggestions for a workaround?

Edit: It appears that a workaround does not exist #4832 ...

Update: Found a hack for a workaround https://github.com/pyproj4/pyproj/pull/1143
Also used in fiona: https://github.com/Toblerity/Fiona/pull/1093
Used by pyogrio: https://github.com/geopandas/pyogrio/search?q=CTE
@snowman2 instead of opting into c code, you can use code generation or a template engine

> What is the recommended path forward since conditional statements are now deprecated?

Right now it's probably to do nothing. The two main alternatives are:
* Move the conditional compilation into C (often more robust, but we realize it relies on people being familiar with C),
* Use code generation or a template engine (they're kind of the same thing). This is likely to be the main recommendation for most cases. It's possible currently but we want to add tools to make it much easier to put into the build pipeline.
We won't be removing anything until well after those tools are available and people have had time to use them.

The current situation is something like "Cython core developers don't like this feature and would like to replace it with a better alternative". It's a statement of intent rather than immediate action. The main consequence right now is that we aren't interesting in proposals extend the current conditional complication feature.

I don't think it's necessary to do a comprehensive Github search and open issues on every project that uses this feature. We'll make sure that suitable warnings appear in Cython well before anything removes, and that the alternatives are well-documented. Until then I'd wait (especially with respect to existing code).

> The current situation is something like "Cython core developers don't like this feature and would like to replace it with a better alternative". It's a statement of intent rather than immediate action. The main consequence right now is that we aren't interesting in proposals extend the current conditional complication feature.

Thanks for the clarification :+1:

> * It's possible currently but we want to add tools to make it much easier to put into the build pipeline.

don't we already have our mini tempita? it's just not exposed to the cython users

> don't we already have our mini tempita? it's just not exposed to the cython users

Yes - the plan is roughly in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2596

> The thing is, just to define a constant, we don't need the whole Python value computation machinery that `DEF` adds to the parser. It would be enough to define constants in `setup.py` and add them to some internal namespace. Or finally implement `cdef const ... =`. Or, inject them with code generation, which covers a whole lot more use cases.

After running into these deprecations in SciPy, a few thoughts on this. SciPy uses `DEF` in a lot of files, almost exclusively to define constants (e.g., tolerances and magic numbers for special functions). Out of the suggested alternatives here:

- `cdef const` sounds like a very nice thing to have here.
- `setup.py` is not available, since we're no longer using `distutils` (true for more and more projects). Either way, needing a separate namespace for some constants seems cumbersome.
- Code generation + Cython is _extremely expensive_ development & maintenance wise. The problem is not doing the templating and code generation, the problem is the combination of an out-of-place build system (mandatory for Meson, good practice for CMake) and the path-dependence of Cython's name determination for extensions. Cython + generated sources has been our number one problem during build system migration. Getting more of those problems just to define constants is not a good thing.

Is there a chance `cdef const` is on its way to being implemented?
Do you have some examples from SciPy that could be shared here?

Here's a good fraction of it:

> Is there a chance cdef const is on its way to being implemented?

PR created: #5242. Only for global variables though.

h5py is also using `IF` quite a bit - mainly to do things conditionally on the HDF5 version (using tuple comparison: `IF HDF5_VERSION >= (1, 8, 13)`), but also for build-time optional features (`IF MPI`). It was something of a surprise to see the flood of warning messages about this.

I think my current inclination might be to add a config option to turn off these warnings (and only these warnings). I think we do want to warn people but it seems a little unhelpful to leave them with no way of turning it off when we haven't really sorted the solution for this.

@scoder As the current maintainer and main dev of __Winloop__ I'm trying to move away from using the `DEF` syntax for my modules and I'm also am planning on making a pull request for __Uvloop__ so that they can do the same as me but when I were to put  `DEFAULT_FREELIST_SIZE` into something like `@cython.freelist` It doesn't work when I do it using your method shown above, is there anyway I can workaround this problem/issue and migrate away from this syntax while allowing `@cython.freelist(DEFAULT_FREELIST_SIZE)` to still work? I have found no good examples for this anywhere in the cython documentation and I think that a section in the cython documentation on migrating away from `DEF` , `IF` and `ELSE` might be necessary in the future.

## Here's the Code

`winloop\includes\consts.pxi`
```cython
DEF UV_STREAM_RECV_BUF_SIZE = 256000  # 250kb

DEF FLOW_CONTROL_HIGH_WATER = 64  # KiB
DEF FLOW_CONTROL_HIGH_WATER_SSL_READ = 256  # KiB
DEF FLOW_CONTROL_HIGH_WATER_SSL_WRITE = 512  # KiB

DEF DEFAULT_FREELIST_SIZE = 250
DEF DNS_PYADDR_TO_SOCKADDR_CACHE_SIZE = 2048

DEF DEBUG_STACK_DEPTH = 10


DEF __PROCESS_DEBUG_SLEEP_AFTER_FORK = 1


DEF LOG_THRESHOLD_FOR_CONNLOST_WRITES = 5


# Number of seconds to wait for SSL handshake to complete
# The default timeout matches that of Nginx.
DEF SSL_HANDSHAKE_TIMEOUT = 60.0
# Number of seconds to wait for SSL shutdown to complete
# The default timeout mimics lingering_time
DEF SSL_SHUTDOWN_TIMEOUT = 30.0
DEF SSL_READ_MAX_SIZE = 256 * 1024
```

In the *Biotite* project compile time (`DEF`) constants are used to resolve computations at compile time that would otherwise happen frequently, e.g. in [this module](https://github.com/biotite-dev/biotite/blob/master/src/biotite/sequence/align/pairwise.pyx):

```cython
DEF MATCH_TO_MATCH       = 1
DEF GAP_LEFT_TO_MATCH    = 2
DEF GAP_TOP_TO_MATCH     = 4

...

for ... :
    trace &= ~(
        MATCH_TO_MATCH |
        GAP_LEFT_TO_MATCH |
        GAP_TOP_TO_MATCH
    )
```

Such computations appear in multiple places. While it would be possible to replace these expressions by a entirely new variable outside the loop, it would in my opinion decrease code readability.

> Such computations appear in multiple places

Your example looks like a C enum might work well for you. Note that the C compiler will compute your or-ed constants at compile time either way, even if Cython doesn't.

> I think my current inclination might be to add a config option to turn off these warnings (and only these warnings). I think we do want to warn people but it seems a little unhelpful to leave them with no way of turning it off when we haven't really sorted the solution for this.

Hi, can we please have this in a next bugfix release? We have a massive wall of deprecation warnings in the SciPy build output that we can't do much about until gh-5242 lands, and it's allowing other problems to slip back in unnoticed.

I can implement it if that helps. I'd just need to know what you prefer - CLI flag, environment variable, or ...?

> I can implement it if that helps. I'd just need to know what you prefer - CLI flag, environment variable, or ...?

I'd suggest add a compiler directive: https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#warnings

> I'd suggest add a compiler directive

Yes, sounds good. Call it `legacy_conditional_compilation`, make the default `None`, let users set it to true to disable the warning, let them set it to false to disable the feature (we can implement that last bit once it's there, `None` and true are ok for now).

> > I'd suggest add a compiler directive
> 
> Yes, sounds good. Call it `legacy_conditional_compilation`, make the default `None`, let users set it to true to disable the warning, let them set it to false to disable the feature (we can implement that last bit once it's there, `None` and true are ok for now).

Hm sorry for jumping in. I don't want to start bike shedding discussion. Currently we have already one legacy compiler directive and it seems that it can pile up in time. Can we have one universal legacy directive enabling legacy features?

e.g. 

`legacy_features = "conditional_compilation, implicit_noexcept, ..."`

I think this will allow us to easier control legacy functionality in Cython.

> I think this will allow us to easier control legacy functionality in Cython.

https://xkcd.com/1172/  ("Workflow"  just add an option!)

I don't want to make "keep this as it is" compiler directives a general feature. Adding one is really bad for everyone because it always means that users will switch them on and forget about them, and then we're back to deprecation step 0 when we really want to change the behaviour later.

AFAICT and IMHO, we currently have three directives for undesired behaviour (I noted the defaults below):
- `allow_none_for_extension_args=True` (this is the wrong default but it predates `Optional[]` by years)
- `preliminary_late_includes_cy28=False` (we never implemented the intended replacement)
- `legacy_implicit_noexcept=False` (it just takes time to adapt large existing code bases)
and we now discuss adding a fourth one:
- `legacy_conditional_compilation=False`

That's already quite a bunch, and their effects are largely untested because they have a fixed value for (almost) the entire test suite. We should have less of those, not more. Adding a compiler directive (especially for legacy features) has a very high cost.

Really, we also should not add this one. The reasons why we still do it are that 1) it can be overwhelming for larger projects to replace all their usages, 2) the option can be disabled gradually per module while migrating step by step, 3) it's not always trivial and obvious which replacement to chose, and 4) there may still be use cases for which we don't have a "good enough" answer. The last one is the real reason why I admit this in.

A more user-friendly alternative that also avoids a new compiler directive would be to just turn this warning off completely (for `DEF` only), and turn it back on once `cdef const global_var` works. Since there's not much use to the warning until that point, given that this is by some distance the most common use case for `DEF`.

> A more user-friendly alternative that also avoids a new compiler directive would be to just turn this warning off completely (for `DEF` only), and turn it back on once `cdef const global_var` works.

I'm inclined to agree. The main user-side problem is `IF`, more than `DEF`. However, the main internal source of complexity is `DEF`, not `IF`, so getting rid of `IF` without also ripping out `DEF` isn't going to help *us* much.


> Since there's not much use to the warning until that point, given that this is by some distance the most common use case for `DEF`.

I'm not sure that is the case, but I can't bring up numbers. We've seen several examples in this discussion where `const` globals were not the best solution. I listed several possible solutions in the ticket description above. I do agree that `const` globals would generally be a nice feature and could help in many cases. It's ugly in Python code, though, as it stands.

In foreign tickets, I regularly sense a lack of guidance as to what users should do to solve their specific problem. It's also difficult to give general advice here. The fact that the feature existed made many developers use it without thinking about better solutions. Deprecating it now means that they have to go back to their old code and find new solutions for each of their use cases. That is work. Work, that is probably better spent writing code and solving the problems of their users.

**Proposal**: let's
1) keep the deprecation of `IF` (which is misused most of the time it is being used)
2) remove the compile time deprecation warning for `DEF` in Cython (pyx) files, but keep the warnings in the documentation
3) keep `DEF` (and `IF`) out of Python files, where it's currently not implemented.

Edit: 4) add a parse time warning when float values are used with `DEF` that do not serialise with the exact digits with which they were entered, i.e. when we know that the C code will not reflect what users see in their Cython code.

Regarding the examples from SciPy that @rgommers posted in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4310#issuecomment-1409550422:

<details>

> ```
> scipy/stats/_stats.pyx
> 35:DEF SQRT2_PI = 0.79788456080286535588  # sqrt(2/pi)
> 
> scipy/special/_wright_bessel.pxd
> 34:DEF rgamma_zero = 178.47241115886637
> 36:DEF exp_inf = 709.78271289338403
> 38:# DEF exp_zero = -745.13321910194117
> 
> scipy/special/_spence.pxd
> 18:DEF TOL = 2.220446092504131e-16
> 19:DEF PISQ_6 = 1.6449340668482264365
> 
> scipy/special/_loggamma.pxd
> 30:DEF TWOPI = 6.2831853071795864769252842 # 2*pi
> 31:DEF LOGPI = 1.1447298858494001741434262 # log(pi)
> 32:DEF HLOG2PI = 0.918938533204672742 # log(2*pi)/2
> 
> scipy/special/_lambertw.pxd
> 29:DEF EXPN1 = 0.36787944117144232159553  # exp(-1)
> 30:DEF OMEGA = 0.56714329040978387299997  # W(1, 0)
> 
> scipy/special/_sici.pxd
> 23:DEF TOL = 2.220446092504131e-16
> 24:DEF EULER = 0.577215664901532860606512090082402431  # Euler constant
> 
> scipy/special/_hyp2f1.pxd
> 75:DEF EPS = 1e-15
> 77:DEF SQRT_PI = 1.7724538509055159  # sqrt(M_PI)
> 78:DEF LOG_PI_2 = 0.5723649429247001  # log(M_PI) / 2
> 
> scipy/special/_hypergeometric.pxd
> 11:DEF EPS = 2.220446049250313e-16
> 12:DEF ACCEPTABLE_RTOL = 1e-7
> 
> scipy/special/_digamma.pxd
> 27:DEF tol = 2.220446092504131e-16
> 30:DEF posroot = 1.4616321449683623
> 32:DEF posrootval = -9.2412655217294275e-17
> 34:DEF negroot = -0.504083008264455409
> 36:DEF negrootval = 7.2897639029768949e-17
> 
> scipy/special/_complexstuff.pxd
> 22:DEF tol = 2.220446092504131e-16
> ```

</details>

I noticed that some of these floating point numbers use a very high precision. Cython parses these as floating point numbers, saves them as Python floats (i.e. C double) internally, and writes them back out using normal Python float serialisation (which, in modern Python 3, tries to find the shortest exact string representation of the 64-bit value). There is no guarantee about the exact fraction digits that you will find in the generated C code, and it depends on the Python implementation/version. Here's the `EULER` constant in Python 3.10:
```python
>>> 0.577215664901532860606512090082402431
0.5772156649015329
```

This is different from floating point literals that you write directly into your source code. `DEF` does not give you literal constants, it's a way more complex system that allows a wide range of Python calculations at parse time, long before types are applied or C code is getting generated. It is based on Python values in a Python namespace. Only when the `DEF`-ed names are used in the "regular" source code, Cython's parser will re-insert the Python values by serialising them back and creating syntax nodes based on the Python value type. This works safely for ~strings and~ integers, but specifically for floating point values, we do not guarantee the precision. (Edit: actually, for strings, it also depends on Python's string semantics, e.g. it allows you to mix text and bytes in Py2, for example, and you get in your C code whatever Python type Python made of it.)

I removed the visible warning message for `DEF` in https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/ac390ce954297a52d537f0f3fb9d2aade296c951 and added a warning for decreased floating point precision in https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/2195767f299f6279fc07317ce4a938e6e11cafdc. Thus, https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4310#issuecomment-1702887983 is now implemented.

Here's my use case of `IF`. Not sure how to work around it:

```cython
# For `get_time_now_ns` and `get_time_now_us` functions.
IF UNAME_SYSNAME == 'Windows':
    import time
ELSE:
    from posix.time cimport timespec, clock_gettime, CLOCK_REALTIME
```

See: https://github.com/questdb/py-questdb-client/blob/4584366f6afafcdac4f860354c48b78da8589eb4/src/questdb/ingress.pyx#L71

> ```cython
> from posix.time cimport timespec, clock_gettime, CLOCK_REALTIME
> ```

You're only using these in two tiny functions. I'd just write a little C shim that uses them, maybe even in verbatim C code directly in the .pyx file. Then you either compile that in using the C preprocessor, or you use the Python fallback that you already have on Windows.

That way, you don't need to generate different C files for each platform.

Just a heads up that the `IF` deprecation is [biting us](https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/34616#issuecomment-1752716116) in Apache Arrow, and any potential workaround seems much more cumbersome and maintenance-heavy that the `IF`-based solution.

Unless it is really a maintenance burden for Cython, it would be nice to undeprecate this feature.
I agree, not an expert in any way but the alternatives seem to be much less straightforward

> alternatives seem to be much less straightforward

Think about it the other way  if the feature wasn't there already, would you want to add it? We would probably reject such a proposal because of the existing alternatives.

The reason why we have visibly deprecated it is to make it clear to users that writing new code that uses this feature is not a good idea.

> Think about it the other way  if the feature wasn't there already, would you want to add it?

Conditional compilation certainly sounds like a basic feature to me, especially when targetting inflexible languages such as C and C++ where all lookups happen at compile-time.

So, given that Cython is meant to be at least as easy to use as C (and far easier in many cases), it sounds logical to want to add it.

> it sounds logical to want to add it.

I understand that developers want to use it. If you give someone a hammer in their hands, they'll start seeing nails all over the place.

But all the user provided examples that I've seen so far in this discussion suggest to me that it's relatively easy (and, really, cleaner in most of the cases) to write the code without this feature but using one of the alternatives.

In your specific case (https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4310#issuecomment-1752850400), I think that a separate module would really avoid all of the `IF  ELSE ` hacks in that PR that make you end up with differently and deeply indented code (which is _always_ more difficult to read). It would make it much easier to separate out all the dependencies on the external library configuration and to collect them in one place.

> But all the user provided examples that I've seen so far in this discussion suggest to me that it's relatively easy (and, really, cleaner in most of the cases) to write the code without this feature but using one of the alternatives.

I don't know how "relatively easy" it would be, but the fact that two experienced developers (@jorisvandenbossche and I) are debating exactly how it can be done seems to hint that it's highly non-trivial.

> Think about it the other way  if the feature wasn't there already, would you want to add it?

Actually the answer is definitely yes, I remember I used the feature because I explicitly searched for it and was glad it fit my use case.

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Deprecate conditional compilation
